bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Wickliffe Rose, April 5, 1921

div1.p: Hanson discusses outbreaks of yellow fever in Peru, and his dealings with the Peruvian government. He requests the use of International Health Board funding.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Wickliffe Rose, April 5, 1921
div1.opener:
COPY.
DIRECCION
de la
CAMPANA SANITARIA
Contra La Fierre Amarilla
en Los Departamentos Del Norte.
Chiclayo, Peru,
April 5, 1921.
Dr. Wickliffe Rose,
General Director,
International Health Board,
New York, N. Y.
Dear Doctor Rose:
div1.p:
I have your letter of the 25th of February, in which you refer to
Dr. Carter's cable, and the one you sent him in Lima, authorizing $5000.00
for yellow fever work in Peru. By this time you no doubt have seen and talked
with Dr. Carter about the situation here.

I have also received you other communications, viz., M. E. Connor's
“Part Played by Fish in Yellow Fever Control in Guayaquil, Ecuador,” and
“Yellow Fever Control in Ecuador” as well as No. 7329, Memorandum in Reference
to FINANCIAL PROCEDURE, OF THE INTERNATIONAL HEALTH BOARD. In regard to the
latter we are studying this to have our accounts conform as far as is possible.

As I have already told you I have used of your funds to bridge over
the time which the Government has taken to arrange their finances for the cam-
paign. During the last days I have been very much worried, because I had used
up practically all your funds, and up to this morning had heard nothing from
Lima. Had it not been for your money, the campaign would have been paralized
during the last three weeks, and the fever certainly would have been well
established in the Province of Pacasmayo. This I think has been avoided as a
result of my taking the liberty to use your money wherever it was necessary to
2
keep the work going at full speed. Saturday night after paying the employees
I found myself without funds, and sent the following cable to Lima:
“Quedan suspendidos trabajos hasta entrega dinero.”

This had been preceded by several messages requesting them to attend to the
matter. On March 22 I sent a radiogram urgently requesting that the matter
be attended to, and had to send another March 29, as follows:

“Salubridad --- Lima. Sirvaso contestarme radiograma fecha
22 actual. Ahora no hay fondos continuar Campana.”
To which the Salubridad replied as follows:
“Dr. Hanson, Chiclayo

Contesto aerograma 22 y 29 actual manifestandole haberme dirigido
tesorero gestionahdo pago presupuosto aprobado resolucion cuatro actual.
Salubridad, Cardenas”
On March 31, I sent the following messages:
“Direccion Tesoro --- Lima

Hasta hoy Tesorero Fiscal no ha recibido ordenes abonar gastos
Campana Sanitaria. He pagado todo con fondos “Rockefeller y estoy
sin fondos continuar y pagar peones semana. Dirijome Presidente mismo
sentido.”
and this:
“PRESIDENT LEGUIA ..... LIMA

RECEIVED NO FUNDS FROM ADUANA. ALL EXPENSES SINCE ARRIVAL PAID
WITH ROCKEFELLER FUNDS. NOTHING LEFT TO CONTINUE WITH.
HANSON”

Only today has the matter been arranged. I have just received no-
tice from the Prefectura, that orders have come from Lima to turn over
Lp. 1000.0.00 to the sanitary campaign. I write you this to give you an
idea of the difficulties we have at times, and of the dangers we confront
in the campaign. As I have stated before, had it not been for the use of
your funds the campaign would have been irretrievably lost during the last
three weeks. In addition to the work in the Department of Lambayeque, all
the expenses of the campaign in Pacasmayo have been from the funds of the
International Health Board, which I believe is the reserve which has broken
the advance.

A resume of the work in the Province of Pacasmayo shows the fol-
lowing:
Total deposits (containers) inspected 10,614
Containers with larvae, destroyed 988

I still have two places in the Province to hear from, Guadelupe
and Pacanga.

Dr. Mendoza has been thoroughly impressed with the importance of
the position which he is holding, and the indications are that he is doing
good work.

On account of what I have indicated above it will be a little dif-
ficult to present a fixed budget, because I anticipate that the government
will be in more difficult financial straits, as time advances. The revolution-
ary spirit is rather appalling, and no one can predict what or when something
will happen.
Last night I sent you the following cable:
“INTERCOM NEW YORK.

FINANCIAL STATUS SUCH APPEARS GOVERNMENT WILL NOT FURNISH
SUFFICIENT FUNDS TO CARRY CAMPAIGN TO SUCCESSFUL CONCLUSION. NEED
AVAILABLE MONTHLY ALLOWANCE TEN THOUSAND DOLLARS ON ACCOUNT EXTENT
TERRITORY TO BE PROTECTED TO INSURE COMPLETE EXTIRPATION THIS YEAR.
EXPLANATORY LETTERS AND ESTIMATE SENT BY MAIL. CABLE ADDRESS
HANSON CHICLAYO.”

Unless you prefer other arrangement, I propose to handle your
funds through the Banco Mercantile Americano, in Chiclayo. I have already
opened an account with this Bank for the money used to date.

Under date of March 25, I wrote you about the budgets for the dif-
ferent Departments, but it appears very doubtful that they will furnish the
amounts indicated. The $10,000 indicated above according to the rate of ex-
change which prevails will be the equivalent of about Lp 2600.0.00. The ex-
change however has fluctuated lately between about 3.70 to 4.20. for the
peruvian pound. I presume that you will advise in more detail what part of
the expense you expect to assume after your conference with Dr. Carter.

In regard to the use of fish, we have already commenced distributing
fish for the larger tanks, and such receptacles as appear appropriate for this
4
type of mosquito control. Here we have, however, a large number of small
containers where the amount of water does not seem sufficient to favor the
use of fish. I discussed this matter with Dr. M.E. Connor when he was in
Lima, and he stated that he thought that a great many of our containers did
not lend themselves to the use of fish with the same degree of success as
in Guayaquil. I shall try the method out as far as is possible. I have
today cabled Guayaquil, Dr. Pareja, to find out if we can purchase a breeding
supply of “Millions” for the use in our campaign. There are places in the
Department of Libertad, such as the Hacienda, Casa Grande, where I believe
they will be the most effective, if not the only successful method which we
can adopt. If we succeed in developing a good breeding ground, we can also
distribute them to help control the culex and anopheles here.

The foci of epidemic in this Department are as follows: Olmos, Motupe,
Salas, Jayanca, Illimo, Tucume, Mochumi, Ferranafe, Lambayeque, Chiclayo, Monsefu,
Villa Eten, Puerto Eten, Cayalti, Sana, Tuman and Pomalca. The epidemic is in
its last stages in Ferrenafe, Chiclayo, Monsefu, Villa Eten, Pomalca, Tuman and
the port of Eten. At the present time it is severe in the north; the report from
Motupe last night gave 31 cases with two deaths, leaving 28. We have adopted
the habit of multiplying the number of cases reported by ten to more accurately
approach the true number of cases existing, which would indicate at least 290
in Motupe.

Col. Vergne of the French Army Medical Corps, who is in Peru with
the French Military Mission as the, or in the capacity corresponding to that
of, Surgeon General for the Peruvian Army Medical Corps, has been in the Department
for about two months and is co-operating like a true ally. He left for Motupe
yesterday for an inspection of the Military post and the condition of the epi-
demic. I have one Dr. Alva Diaz, and four inspectors working there.

Dol. Vergne with a detachment from the Army is to take charge of the
5
sector in the southern part of this Province (Province of Chiclayo). He too
is having difficulties in securing the necessary orders and co-operation from
the Commanding Officer of the Section. He is one (the C.O.) of those who
profess not to believe in yellow fever.

I have had conference with the managers of the daily papers which
were writing the scurrilous propaganda against the campaign, and have suc-
ceeded in suppressing such propaganda as that, of which I sent you samples.
My principal difficulty in the personnel is with the Medico Titular, nom-
inated for this province by the Direccion de Salubridad. He is a person
without experience or judgment and is the main source of the opposition which
we have at the present time. He does not figure in my budget; if he did, I
would discharge him without delay.

The medical students sent up by the Direccion de Salubridad, also
are of no value, and I shall recommend their recall, thereby saving Lp 100.0.00
monthly.

I have no code available here, other than a commercial code at the
Bank, and that does not give a saving in expense.
Under separate cover I send detailed estimate for campaign.
